105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: The State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., imposes duties on landlords to maintain residential dwellings in a condition that does not endanger or materially impair the health or safety of the occupants, including requirements that bathrooms be adequately ventilated and kept free from chronic dampness and mold that may affect health.

105 C.M.R. 410.100 (ventilation), 410.75.proposition: The State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., imposes duties on landlords to maintain residential dwellings in a condition that does not endanger or materially impair the health or safety of the occupants, including requirements that bathrooms be adequately ventilated and kept free from chronic dampness and mold that may affect health.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential tenancy includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The court expressly states that “every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant” of quiet enjoyment, and it does so specifically in the context of residential premises and G.L. c. 186, § 14. This directly supports the proposition that, under Massachusetts law, residential tenancies include an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977).” (385 Mass. at 102)

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 283–84 (1994).
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is breached when the landlord, by act or omission, causes a serious interference with the tenant’s right to use and enjoy the premises. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. at 102–04; Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 283–84 (1994).
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly defines the covenant of quiet enjoyment as protecting tenants from serious interference with their tenancy caused by the landlord’s acts or omissions, and applies that standard to the landlord’s failure to act against drug-related activity. The court states that a landlord may breach the covenant when a serious interference with the tenancy is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted to be done, which matches the proposition’s formulation.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … If the defendant failed to take any action… then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771, 776–77 (1994).
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.proposition: A landlord’s failure to maintain the premises in compliance with the state Sanitary Code and health and safety requirements can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771, 776–77 (1994); Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850–51 (1997).
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses breach of the implied warranty of habitability, damages, and the interaction with Section 8 subsidies, but it does not analyze or hold that failure to comply with the State Sanitary Code or health and safety requirements constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The only mention of quiet enjoyment is that the judge found such a breach but awarded no damages to avoid duplication; there is no substantive treatment linking Sanitary Code violations to quiet enjoyment. Thus, this case does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.relevant_excerpt: Although the judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, he awarded no damages on this claim to avoid what would have been a duplicative award. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 107-111 (1982).

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: A landlord’s failure to maintain the premises in compliance with the state Sanitary Code and health and safety requirements can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771, 776–77 (1994); Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850–51 (1997).
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: The opinion’s main holding is that a bare statutory violation (here, the lead paint statute) does not, by itself, establish a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment; some degree of landlord fault (at least negligence, based on notice or reason to know) is required. In reaching that conclusion, however, the court reaffirms that a landlord’s failure to repair code-related defects of which the landlord has notice—including conditions governed by the State Sanitary Code and health and safety requirements—can constitute a § 14 quiet enjoyment violation. Thus, while the case narrows strict-liability arguments, it supports the broader proposition that negligent failure to maintain code-compliant, safe premises can breach quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt: “Twelve years later, in Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas, supra, we rejected a claim that a violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14, could be imposed only if it were proved that a landlord was reckless in disregarding his tenant’s rights, and we concluded that negligent conduct, conduct involving ‘some degree of fault,’ by a landlord could support the imposition of liability under § 14. Id. at 789. We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’”}

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199–201 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: In Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199–201 (1973), the Supreme Judicial Court held that substantial code violations affecting health and safety can constitute a breach of obligations owed to the tenant and justify rent abatement and other remedies.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: The quoted text is from Justice Quirico’s separate opinion, but even he expressly agrees that, where there are substantial State Sanitary Code violations, the tenant’s rent liability may be reduced to the fair value of use and occupancy in the unit’s deficient condition. He would ground the landlord’s obligation in statutory code-compliance rather than a broad implied warranty, but he accepts that code violations affecting health and safety create enforceable obligations owed to tenants and justify rent abatement-type remedies. The majority opinion (not reproduced here) goes further in adopting an implied warranty of habitability, so the case as a whole supports the proposition.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “I dissent … for the reason, in part, that it would be sufficient for the decision of these cases to hold that the landlord, in renting the apartments to the tenants, impliedly agreed that the apartments would comply with the several requirements of the Code which the tenants allege were violated, and that if the tenants sustain their burden of proof of such violations their liability for the unpaid rent may be reduced to the fair value of their use and occupancy of the apartments in their deficient condition.”

Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.raw_text: Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744, 748–50 (2005)
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.proposition: A landlord may be liable under G.L. c. 186, § 14 for conditions that the landlord knows about and fails to remedy with reasonable diligence, where those conditions substantially interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. See Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744, 748–50 (2005); Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983 (1982).
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss G.L. c. 186, § 14 and reiterates that quiet enjoyment protects tenants from serious interference, generally requiring that the landlord have notice and act at least negligently in failing to alleviate the condition. However, the court holds that there was no breach because the landlord acted immediately upon notice and remedied the issues, so it does not actually find liability or expressly state that a landlord is liable under § 14 for failing to remedy known conditions with reasonable diligence. The proposition describes a standard that is consistent with Massachusetts law, but this particular case applies that standard to reject, not impose, liability.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.relevant_excerpt:
We have interpreted this obligation to mean that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interference with her tenancy. See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Authy., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994). Generally, the landlord must have had notice of the condition interfering with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises, and he must have at least acted negligently in not alleviating the condition. See Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850-851 (1997).

Here, York acted immediately upon being notified by Casey of the defective conditions. ... The trial judge did not err in denying the requested ruling of law that a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment had occurred.

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983 (1982).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: A landlord may be liable under G.L. c. 186, § 14 for conditions that the landlord knows about and fails to remedy with reasonable diligence, where those conditions substantially interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. See Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744, 748–50 (2005); Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983 (1982).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat that substantially impairs the value of the premises constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, regardless of the landlord’s financial inability or lack of intent. However, it does not analyze liability in terms of the landlord merely ‘knowing of’ a condition and ‘failing to remedy it with reasonable diligence’; instead, it focuses on the effect of the landlord’s conduct and the natural and probable consequences. Thus, the case supports strict-effect-based liability for failure to furnish heat, but not the specific ‘knows and fails to remedy with reasonable diligence’ formulation in the proposition.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season … seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’ … [L]iability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 399\u.proposition: A tenant prevailing on a claim under G.L. c. 186, § 14 is entitled to “actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater,” as well as reasonable attorney’s fees and costs. See Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 399–401 (1982).
Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 399\u.support_reasoning: The court explicitly describes the remedial scheme under G.L. c. 186, § 14, stating that it allows tenants to recover “actual and consequential damages or three month’s rent, whichever is greater.” The opinion also recognizes that a tenant prevailing on such a claim may recover damages under this provision (though it ultimately disallows duplicative recovery where a larger G.L. c. 93A award has been made). While this case does not itself award attorney’s fees and costs under § 14, it accurately states the damages formula that the proposition quotes.
Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 399\u.relevant_excerpt: “The judge awarded $990 (three months’ rent) to the tenants on a finding that the landlord had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14, the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment. General Laws c. 186, § 14, as amended by St. 1974, c. 192, § 1, allows tenants to recover ‘actual and consequential damages or three month’s rent, whichever is greater,’ for violation of that statute.”
